title: How to Make Waterproof Fire Starters

steps.headline: Stuff the egg carton with as much lint as you can get in there.
steps.description: The more lint you have, the longer the fire starter will burn.

steps.headline: Break apart your egg carton.
steps.description: You can try cutting them, but you may just want to use your hands. As you break them apart, make sure that you leave 4 taller sections on each corner of the separate pieces, as you will need those for the next step.

steps.headline: Fold the corners of your egg carton into the middle.
Prepare your wax.
steps.description: First, break your wax into small pieces and put them inside of your aluminum can or glass jar. Then, place the aluminum can inside of the pot. Next, fill the pot with only enough water to slightly lift up your can. Too much water and the can will tip over. Finally, place the pot on the stove, medium heat, for about 5-10 minutes.

steps.headline: Grab your dental floss or string.
steps.description: Cut 12 pieces of string (about as long as your forearm and hand) and place the fire starters in the middle of the string. Then double knot your string around the fire starter, effectively sealing it closed. You want to make sure you have enough length in your string to dip the fire starter into the hot wax while keeping your hand away from the steam.

steps.headline: Set up your workstation.
steps.description: Next to the pot of boiling water, make sure you have your cardboard or paper towels ready, the plastic knife, and your fire starters.

steps.headline: Holding the end of the string, dip the fire starters into the wax.
steps.description: Use the plastic knife to hold the fire starter completely under until it stops bubbling. This allows the dryer lint to soak up as much wax as possible, effectively increasing your burning time. Once they stop bubbling, remove them and put them on the cardboard. Allow to dry for about two hours.

steps.headline: Snip off the ends of your floss or string.
steps.description: Try to keep the string tied around the fire starter, because the string makes it easier to light. Your fire starters are now ready to go! Completely waterproof, they are ready for wherever your adventure takes you.

methods.name:
Petroleum Jelly Fire Starter[1]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Melt a tablespoon or two of petroleum jelly.
steps.description: Place the jelly into a small pan and melt over low heat. Pour the melted jelly into a bowl. You will need to gauge how much jelly to use depending on how many fire starters you wish to make. The cotton will readily soak up the melted jelly, so if you want more than 1-2 balls, use more petroleum jelly.

steps.headline: Soak a cotton ball in the petroleum jelly.
steps.description: Dip each cotton ball individually into the bowl of melted jelly, move around to coat well.

steps.headline: Remove the petroleum jelly-saturated cotton ball.
steps.description:
Repeat until you have as many as you want (melt more jelly if needed). Let them cool and dry. Once dried, store them safely with your other camping and outdoor survival gear. If you want to make this easier to store and transport you will need to:
Melt candle wax or other wax first to make a holding medium. Pour a small amount of the melted wax into the bottom of a silicone ice-cube mold, then let it solidify. Place the cotton balls (soaked in petroleum jelly) into the molds. Fill the remainder of the mold with melted wax, over the top of each cotton ball. Allow the wax to solidify in the mold. Once a solid cube has formed, remove and wrap each cube individually in aluminum foil for storage.

steps.headline: Use as needed.
steps.description:
To use:
For the non-wrapped fire starter balls: Place a cotton ball under your tinder and kindling and light it. It should burn for a few minutes, long enough for your slightly damp wood to start to catch fire. For the wrapped fire starter cubes: Unwrap and break the wax "cube" to expose the cotton, then light it. It will burn for 7-12 minutes (depending on the size of the cube "mold."

text:
Lint and Wax Fire Starter Stuff the egg carton with as much lint as you can get in there. The more lint you have, the longer the fire starter will burn. Break apart your egg carton. You can try cutting them, but you may just want to use your hands. As you break them apart, make sure that you leave 4 taller sections on each corner of the separate pieces, as you will need those for the next step. Fold the corners of your egg carton into the middle.  Prepare your wax. First, break your wax into small pieces and put them inside of your aluminum can or glass jar. Then, place the aluminum can inside of the pot. Next, fill the pot with only enough water to slightly lift up your can. Too much water and the can will tip over. Finally, place the pot on the stove, medium heat, for about 5-10 minutes. Grab your dental floss or string. Cut 12 pieces of string (about as long as your forearm and hand) and place the fire starters in the middle of the string. Then double knot your string around the fire starter, effectively sealing it closed. You want to make sure you have enough length in your string to dip the fire starter into the hot wax while keeping your hand away from the steam. Set up your workstation. Next to the pot of boiling water, make sure you have your cardboard or paper towels ready, the plastic knife, and your fire starters. Holding the end of the string, dip the fire starters into the wax. Use the plastic knife to hold the fire starter completely under until it stops bubbling. This allows the dryer lint to soak up as much wax as possible, effectively increasing your burning time. Once they stop bubbling, remove them and put them on the cardboard. Allow to dry for about two hours. Snip off the ends of your floss or string. Try to keep the string tied around the fire starter, because the string makes it easier to light. Your fire starters are now ready to go! Completely waterproof, they are ready for wherever your adventure takes you. Petroleum Jelly Fire Starter[1]
	X
		Research source Melt a tablespoon or two of petroleum jelly. Place the jelly into a small pan and melt over low heat. Pour the melted jelly into a bowl. You will need to gauge how much jelly to use depending on how many fire starters you wish to make. The cotton will readily soak up the melted jelly, so if you want more than 1-2 balls, use more petroleum jelly. Soak a cotton ball in the petroleum jelly. Dip each cotton ball individually into the bowl of melted jelly, move around to coat well. Remove the petroleum jelly-saturated cotton ball. Repeat until you have as many as you want (melt more jelly if needed). Let them cool and dry. Once dried, store them safely with your other camping and outdoor survival gear. If you want to make this easier to store and transport you will need to:
Melt candle wax or other wax first to make a holding medium. Pour a small amount of the melted wax into the bottom of a silicone ice-cube mold, then let it solidify. Place the cotton balls (soaked in petroleum jelly) into the molds. Fill the remainder of the mold with melted wax, over the top of each cotton ball. Allow the wax to solidify in the mold. Once a solid cube has formed, remove and wrap each cube individually in aluminum foil for storage. Use as needed. To use:
For the non-wrapped fire starter balls: Place a cotton ball under your tinder and kindling and light it. It should burn for a few minutes, long enough for your slightly damp wood to start to catch fire. For the wrapped fire starter cubes: Unwrap and break the wax "cube" to expose the cotton, then light it. It will burn for 7-12 minutes (depending on the size of the cube "mold."
